title: 115_s1072
content:
The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans under certain conditions. Services covered may include care for a dependent while the homeless veteran receives services from the grant recipient. Partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to enter partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, funding general legal services for this purpose. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can partner with public or private entities to fund general legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Partnerships should be distributed equitably across the United States, including rural communities, tribal lands, Native Americans, and tribal organizations. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include housing-related legal assistance such as eviction defense and representation in landlord-tenant cases, as well as family law services. Legal services for homelessness include legal assistance for housing, family law, income support, and criminal defense. Legal services related to criminal defense, including defense in matters like outstanding warrants, fines, and driver's license revocation, to reduce recidivism and help with reentry obstacles in employment or housing. Other legal services as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. Consultation with public and private entities for assistance in identifying and contacting. The Secretary may consult with public and private entities to develop partnerships for providing legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. Entities entering into partnerships may be required to submit periodic reports on the legal services provided. The Secretary may require entities in partnerships to submit periodic reports on legal services provided to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to extend eligibility for care to veterans enrolled under section 1705(a) receiving housing assistance or care in specified settings for 60 consecutive days. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide dental care to homeless veterans enrolled in housing assistance or care in specific settings for 60 consecutive days under the States Housing Act of 1937. The Secretary may provide funds for a grant and per diem provider in specific settings for homeless veterans under the States Housing Act of 1937, disregarding breaks in care not caused by the veteran. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code, is amended by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d).

SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing is amended to allocate $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2017. Training entities for provision of supportive services are extended through 2017. The Comptroller General is required to study the Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on Department of Veterans Affairs programs assisting homeless veterans, including assessing program effectiveness and reviewing efforts to improve services for female veterans. SEC. 8. REPEAL OF REQUIREMENT FOR ANNUAL REPORTS ON ASSISTANCE TO HOMELESS VETERANS. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, is repealed. The table of sections in chapter 20 of such title is amended accordingly.
